question: Does the VgrG (TssI) protein of the Type VI secretion system form a spike at the tip of the tube that penetrates target cell membranes? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: The T6SS organelle is functionally analogous to contractile tails of bacteriophages and is thought to attack cells by initially penetrating them with a trimeric protein complex called the VgrG spike.
content.source_2: Cryo-electron tomography of intact Type VI assemblies placed VgrG/TssI within the baseplate rather than at the distal tip, and target-cell membranes were pierced by a PAAR-only needle that capped the Hcp tube independently of VgrG.
content.source_3: Here we report that proteins from the PAAR (proline-alanine-alanine-arginine) repeat superfamily form a sharp conical extension on the VgrG spike, which is further involved in attaching effector domains to the spike.
content.source_4: In genetic and reconstitution assays, deletion or enforced monomerization of VgrG/TssI had no measurable effect on membrane puncture, whereas contraction of an uncapped Hcp tube was sufficient to disrupt lipid bilayers, arguing against a VgrG tip spike as the puncturing element.
